acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since its 72-hour EC50 = 0.55 mg/L for algae (Pseudokirchneriella subcapitata) (NICNAS, 1996), the substance was classified into Category 1.

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: In the tests using male rats, no mortality occurred at doses up to 1000 mg/kg (NICNAS (1996)). This result indicates that the substance falls under Category 4 or "Not classified" category; however, due to lack of additional data, it was classified into the "Classification not possible" category.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: In rat tests (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.1 NICNAS (1996)), LD50 values were estimated as 224 mg/kg for male rats and 168 mg/kg for female rats (NICNAS (1996)). Based on these values, the substance was classified into Category 3. It is rated as T; R25 in the EU classification.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Its classification for acute toxicity is Category 1, and we judged that it is not rapidly degradable as reliable information on its rapid degradability was not available. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_solids.rationale: No data available. There is a description that the substance is not flammable (NICNAS (1996)).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative results obtained in micronucleus tests using mouse bone marrow cells (in vivo mutagenicity tests using somatic cells) (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.12 NICNAS (1996)), the substance was classified into "Not classified". Negative results were also reported in vivo genotoxicity tests using somatic cells (unscheduled DNA synthesis tests using mouse liver) (NICNAS (1996)). In addition, regarding in vitro mutagenicity tests, gene mutation tests using microorganisms (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.14), gene mutation tests using cultured mammalian cells, and non-bacteriological in vitro tests (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.10) all gave negative results (NICNAS (1996)).

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_solids.rationale: The substance contains oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine) which is chemically bonded only to carbon.

self_heating_substances.rationale: No data available. There is a description that the substance is not flammable (NICNAS (1996)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: In the tests in which the substance was applied to the eyes of rabbits (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.5 NICNAS (1996)), severe erythema (Draize score: 3), chemosis (Draize score: 4), mild eye mucus (Draize score: 1), and moderate erythema in eyelids were observed 1 hour after application, leading to the conclusion that the substance is an extremely severe irritant. Based on this report, the substance was classified into Category 1. It is rated as Xi; R41 in the EU classification.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: In rabbit tests (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.4 NICNAS (1996)), mild erythema and edema were detected, and average scores for erythema and edema were less than 1.5 in evaluations conducted in 24, 48 and 72 hours (NICNAS (1996)). Average scores of less than 1.5 for erythema and edema represent the "Not classified" category. It is documented that 9-day repeated toxicity (dermal route) tests using rats showed severe irritation and necrosis (NICNAS (1996)).

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale: The tests using guinea pigs (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.6 NICNAS (1996)) found that the substance is a strong irritant (18 out of 20 rats after 24 hours at 0.3%; 9 out of 20 rats after 48 hours at 0.3%; 20 out of 20 rats after 24 hours at 1%; and 20 out of 20 rats after 48 hours at 1%), and it is rated as R43 by the EU. Thus, the substance was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: According to 28-day oral administration tests using rats fed on mixed diet (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.7 NICNAS (1996)), no effects of administration were detected other than an increased testis weight in male rats at 1000 ppm which was the highest dose tested (90-day conversion: 16.7 mg/kg, which falls under Category 2 guidance value range). However, due to insufficient data available, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible".

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In single oral administration tests using rats (directive 92/69/EEC (1) Test B.1), no effects of administration were detected in male rats and slight toxicity was detected in female rats at a 50 mg/kg concentration, and toxic symptoms were observed for 4 days. At a 100 mg/kg concentration, extreme toxic symptoms were detected in one female rat, and at 500 mg/kg, all treated animals showed extreme toxic symptoms (NICNAS (1996)). In spite of these results documented, the substance was classified into "Classification not possible" due to insufficient data on general symptoms, hematological and biochemical changes, and pathological observations.
